Alexander Fleming

Discoverer of penicillin.

Here is a short timeline of Alexander Fleming's life:

  • 1881- Born in Ayshire, Scotland.
  • 1903- Enrolled in St Mary's Hospital Medical School in London
  • 1906- Graduated with an MBBS degree.
  • 1908- Graduated with a Bachelor's in Bacteriology and became a lecturer at St Mary's.
  • 1914- Became a lieutenant and worked as a soldier in the Royal Army Medical Corps throughout World War 1. During his service, he saw many soldiers die from sepsis as a result of infected wounds.
  • 1928- became Professor of Bacteriology of the University of London. After returning to his lab from a vacation, he noticed that a contaminated culture had a fungus that killed the surrounding staph. This led to his famous discovery.
  • 1929- published his findings into the British Journal of Experimental Pathology. His findings received little attention.
  • 1940- Ernst Boris Chain and Edward Abraham continued Fleming's work to make penicilin consumable. They published the correct molecular structure for the antibiotic.
  • 1943- Elected a Fellow of the Royal Society
  • 1945- Chain and Abraham discovered a way to produce penicilin on an industrial scale. Fleming, Chain, and Abraham all received the Nobel Prize of Medicine.
  • 1951- Elected Rector of the University of Edinburgh.
  • 1955- Died at the age of 73.
